overview_of_class: This course covers the new venture from concept to capital using a hybrid case study method. While the course focuses on the U.S. market and the lifecycle between business plan and the first major transition of equity, the course also touches on regulatory structures, financing projections, debt and convertible debt strategies, traditional and non-traditional compensation, and market conditions analysis. The central component of the course is building the student's capacity, vocabulary, and instincts for strategic thinking, which is stimulated through in-class debates, discussions, and activities. We'll look at companies that are early in the process and get updates through the quarter from senior management on their progress and problems; we'll also look at later-stage companies and the challenges they face as an equity transition, IPO, buyout, or management transition approaches. Students are expected to be prepared for a challenging conversation each week.
name: Entrepreneurship and Technology
title: SCS ORG_BEH 369-CN-12 Entrepreneurship and Technology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the new venture from concept to capital using a hybrid case study method. While the course focuses on the U.S. market and the lifecycle between business plan and the first major transition of equity, the course also touches on regulatory structures, financing projections, debt and convertible debt strategies, traditional and non-traditional compensation, and market conditions analysis. The central component of the course is building the student's capacity, vocabulary, and instincts for strategic thinking, which is stimulated through in-class debates, discussions, and activities. We'll look at companies that are early in the process and get updates through the quarter from senior management on their progress and problems; we'll also look at later-stage companies and the challenges they face as an equity transition, IPO, buyout, or management transition approaches. Students are expected to be prepared for a challenging conversation each week.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students should be ready to read about topics they may not be familiar about and engage with examples from a range of industries, from software to aerospace to videogames to automotive to commercial space travel. But the key prerequisite for this course is intellectual preparedness: You should be ready to debate, consider, and improve ideas in the classroom. This is a social, discussion-driven class. It is more like working for a startup than receiving a lecture.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Explain what technology, innovation, and other concepts mean in the current landscape.

Examine strategies of technology and non-technology companies in the context of case studies, examples, historical analogies, and class discussions.

Write summaries of companies that are following an arc that includes technology, innovation, and adoption of new ideas. Examine these paths with an eye toward profitability and market position.

Consider the human resources, capital needs, and intellectual property requirements of innovation and what non-monetary challenges face companies looking to adopt technology or become more innovative.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is no reading list for this course. The reading list is made up of documents I will provide, including links to recent news items, reports on recent technological innovations, and historical documents I may show in class outlining the success or failure of companies in and out of the technology sector.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is aimed at anyone interested in the role of technology in new companies, including those interested in starting a business. The instructor's view is that all companies are technology companies, or must have a technology component/strategy to succeed. We take a broad view of technology that not only includes the world of computers, software, and apps, but includes other technologies like Amazon's use of UPS shipping services (a logistics technology problem) and small clinics' struggles to adopt HIPAA-compliant recordkeeping systems (a data warehousing technology problem). Students should be ready to be quick on their feet, to be part of the discussion, and to contribute to the debate.

subject: ORG_BEH
